awd_titl_txt: Conference: 13th IRM Conference on Rock Magnetism
awd_abstract_narration:
Advances in research on magnetism and magnetic materials are occurring in geophysics, geochemistry, nanoscience, condensed-matter physics, and to a great extent, along the boundaries between these fields. An interdisciplinary discussion of critical developments in the applications of fine particle magnetism in the geosciences, as well as their fundamental physical foundations, will help to advance our understanding of Earth's surface environment, tectonic history, and its deep interior dynamics. This award supports the Conference on Rock Magnetism and its Applications, June 5-8, 2023 in Minneapolis, MN, continuing a biennial series of conferences started in 1992. 

The broad goal of the Summer Conference series is to bring together present and future leaders in the field for in-depth discussion of fundamental aspects of rock and mineral magnetism, and applications in global geophysics, tectonics, extraterrestrial magnetism, and surficial
environmental studies; these discussions are intended to be more intensive, interactive and sustained. One explicit aim of the 2023 conference is to explore iron cycling through time and a leading expert on the biogeochemistry iron cycle will be invited as a keynote speaker and participant. Another key objective is to discuss grand challenges in paleogeography and tectonics. Students and early career researchers will be supported to attend the meeting. A session is planned to discuss increasing diversity in the US paleomagnetism and rock magnetism community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Geomagnetism is a vibrant core discipline within geophysics. Since 1992 the Institute for Rock Magnetism (IRM) has organized regular three-day biennial conferences to survey the frontiers of research on natural magnetic oxide, hydroxide and sulfide minerals, working from a basis in fundamental physics to applications throughout the Earth and Planetary Sciences. The meetings are small and interactive, allowing more in-depth discussion than larger professional conferences, but they are also international and cross-disciplinary.

Like the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Chapman or Geological Society of America Penrose conferences, they provide an opportunity for frank, informal, in-depth discussion of progress and challenges in major areas of current research, in this case with a focus on fine-particle magnetism and its wide intersection with the geosciences. They are exploratory workshops, bringing together leading researchers in rock magnetism and related fields to catalyze fresh directions of research by identifying critical new problems and innovative interdisciplinary approaches. They afford young scientists and graduate students the opportunity to meet and interact with leading international researchers, gaining deeper understanding and broader perspective, and forming a basis for future collaborations.

The 2023 conference was held at the University of Minnesota, Twin-Cities Campus, June 5-8, 2023. Fifty-nine people attended in-person, with a further 38 remotely through Zoom. Twentyfour participants were students (undergraduates and graduates; 12 in-person and 12 online), and three students were invited to give lectures on their research, and eight presented in the poster session.

There were two days of talks and poster presentations, including two keynote talks, whose aim is to bring in high-level researchers to discuss themes that are complementary to rock magnetism. Keynote speakers at the 2023 conference were Timothy Lyons (UC-Riverside) presenting 'Iron Cycling throughout Earth History' and Emily Cooperdock (Brown University) presenting 'The Timing and Dating of Magnetite Growth'. There were four topical sessions: Iron Cycling in Natural and Anthropogenic Environments, Frontiers in Magnetic Microscopy and Micromagnetic Modeling, Grand Challenges in Paleogeography and Tectonics, and Fundamentals in Rock Magnetism. Each session had four invited speakers, who presented for ~25 minutes with an additional 15 to 20 minutes for discussion.

The conference also included two workshops: a pre-conference workshop on First-Order Reversal Curves (FORCs) and a post-conference community discussion on 'Implementing Justice, Equity, Diversity & Inclusivity (JEDI)'. The FORC workshop covered the fundamentals of the measurements, how to optimize data collection and processing, and mathematical treatment of FORC data to understand end-member contributions. The community workshop summarized diversity data that was collected prior to the meeting across the geomagnetism and paleomagnetism community (e.g., from AGU, IAGA VI, recent publications, and a recent public survey) by co-PI Feinberg and participants presented examples of ongoing JEDI activities at their home institutions in which they are involved and that are potentially scalable across the entire community. In a structured discussion, the results of these findings were synthesized to identify cross-institutional strategies for improving diversity in our communities.

All presentations are available to the general public through the Institute for Rock Magnetism's YouTube page at https://www.youtube.com/@instituteforrockmagnetism685 and a full overview of conference activities can be found in the Institute for Rock Magnetism's Quaterly magazine, Volume 33 Number 2, at https://cse.umn.edu/irm/irm-quarterly.
